results:
Based on the search results, here's what I found about the relationship between Alice Liddell and Lewis Carroll, and their famous boat trip on July 4, 1862:

## The "Golden Afternoon" - July 4, 1862

On July 4, 1862, Charles Dodgson (Lewis Carroll) took Alice Liddell and her sisters on a boat trip that would become known as the "golden afternoon."(no content)The rowing boat departed from Folly Bridge in Oxford, carrying Charles Dodgson, the Reverend Robinson Duckworth, and the three daughters of Henry Liddell, the Dean of Christ Church.(no content)During this boat trip on the River Thames near Oxford, Dodgson first told the story of Alice's adventures, which took place between Folly Bridge and the village of Godstow.(no content)Alice, who was just ten years old at the time, begged Carroll to tell them a story.

## The Story's Creation

During the trip, Dodgson began to tell the sisters the story of a little girl who followed a rabbit down a rabbit hole.(no content)Alice Liddell recalled, "the stories must have been better than usual," and she pleaded: "Oh, Mr. Dodgson, I wish you would write out Alice's adventures for me."(no content)The next day, on a train trip to London, Lewis Carroll drew up chapter headings for the book he originally called Alice's Adventures Underground.(no content)The first edition of Alice's Adventures in Wonderland reached Alice exactly three years later, illustrated by Sir John Tenniel.

## The Relationship Between Carroll and Alice

Charles Dodgson was a mathematics professor at Christ Church when he first met Alice and her family.(no content)At that time, all the dons had to be members of the clergy, single, and supposedly celibate.(no content)Carroll was particularly fond of Alice Liddell, the second of the three Liddell sisters. However, within two years of Alice's first telling, Alice's mother made it clear that she did not welcome a friendship between her daughter and a man 20 years older.(no content)Despite his continued estrangement from Alice and her family, he kept her up-to-date with the success of "her adventures," as he always referred to them.

## Carroll's Character and Photography

Carroll was described as "an unfailingly considerate and honest man, whose moral standards were, as Alice Liddell described his physical posture, 'almost more than upright, as if he had swallowed a poker.'"(no content)Charles Dodgson was an early enthusiast of the art of photography.(no content)He took many photographs of the people he knew, including the young Alice Liddell.

## The Poem "All in the Golden Afternoon"

Carroll later recalled that "golden afternoon" in a poem that prefaces many editions of Alice's Adventures in Wonderland. The poem begins with the lines "All in the golden afternoon / Full leisurely we glide..."

The boat trip on July 4, 1862, remains one of the most significant moments in literary history, marking the birth of one of the world's most beloved children's stories.
